text: [Music]
AWS frees us up to innovate by taking
risks that might not have paid off in
the past the lower risk of releasing a
feature when it only takes a couple of
days to develop and release to
production allows us to run hundreds
more experiments than we were able to
run before
[Music]
my name is Lauren Kobashi obits I'm the
technical director for Asia for Expedia
and specifically our joint venture with
AirAsia AAA etravel we were one of the
earlier teams at Expedia to be
aggressively moving to AWS and you know
we did that because we were building a
new site and we're building it in Asia
and targeting a Southeast Asian customer
base and Expedia has no data center
presence on that side of the world and
we really wanted our application to be
close to our customers so using a device
as a hosting platform allowed us to get
the application closer to our customers
and off the ground
incredibly fast the first and the most
important reason we go with AWS is for
the self-service flexibility I mean the
fact that we can be up and running with
a test environment in minutes that we
can try out new ideas and we don't need
to a pre-scheduled hardware for it I
think if we had decided to grow a
business decisive area to go in Asia in
a classic model I'd probably still be
negotiating datacenter contracts across
Expedia globally we were pushing more
and more services that we want to be
closer to the end customer into AWS and
so we started with it just looking at it
as a hosting provider but since then
have moved on to using a number of other
services we use SNS we use sqs we use an
elastic load balancer we use cloud front
we're certainly heavy users of s3 on the
global Expedia side we have several V
pcs across multiple regions and in each
of those regions we have a test V PC and
we have a production V PC and those V
pcs are connected back to our data
center so that we can securely access
our internal services the most important
benefits from AWS is definitely the
flexibility the ability to get our
application deployed and tested and
released to customers in 20 minutes an
example of that is the system we call
our global deals engine we've migrated
to AWS so that we can have it
scaled out across multiple multiple
regions around the world and we can get
the interactivity that customers are
looking for so that we can get responses
back to the customer in sub-second times
a device allows us get experimental
features to customers at a very low cost
which significantly reduces the risk and
allows us to take bets on on things that
otherwise you wouldn't have necessarily
made the investment in as far as the
future of hosting goes AWS completely
knocked it out of the park and I'm
really excited to see what you guys come
out with next
[Music]
